item.title: Lung Cancer less likely if vitamin D (higher level or supplement) – meta-analysis
Cancer deaths strongly related to low vitamin D if sampled near time of diagnosis
item.description:
Serum levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D and survival in Norwegian patients with cancer of breast, colon, lung, and lymphoma: a population-based study.

Cancer Causes Control. 2012 Feb;23(2):363-70. doi: 10.1007/s10552-011-9885-6.

Tretli S1, Schwartz GG, Torjesen PA, Robsahm TE.

1The Cancer Registry of Norway, Institute of Population-based Cancer Research, Majorstuen, 0304 Oslo, Norway. steinar.tretli@kreftregisteret.no

PURPOSE:

We investigated the association between serum levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25-OHD) and risk of death in Norwegian cancer patients.

METHODS:

item.title: Lung cancer death reduction: CT scan or Vitamin D – which is 40X less expensive
item.description:
It is proposed that Medicare pay $9 billion a year for CT scans of people who have smoked more than 30 packs per year.

The additional CT scans are expected to reduce the death due to lung cancer by 20%

The cost of the annual CT scans about $800 per person (The costs of resulting surgery were not mentioned)

The cost of vitamin D to get a similar reduction appears to be $5/year

item.title: Vitamin A may hinder vitamin D benefits associated with Lung Cancer
item.description:
Vitamin D, Interaction with Vitamin A and Lung Cancer

Cheng, Ting-Yuan, PhD dissertation, University of Washington, July 2013

Vitamin D inhibits several pathways of lung cancer carcinogenesis and cells in the respiratory tract produce and utilize vitamin D.

Vitamin D’s functions rely on vitamin D receptor together with retinoid X receptor, which ligands with 9-cis-retinoic acid, a vitamin A (retinol) metabolite.

The objectives of this dissertation are to investigate

  1. whether high versus low vitamin D intake is associated with lower lung cancer incidence,

item.title: Vitamin D protects against lung cancer unless there is excess vitamin A
item.description:
Serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D, vitamin A, and lung cancer mortality in the US population: a potential nutrient-nutrient interaction.

Cancer Causes Control. 2012 Jul 25.

Cheng TY, Neuhouser ML.

Public Health Sciences Division, Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, 1100 Fairview Avenue North, M4B402, Seattle, WA, 98109-1024, USA, tcheng@fhcrc.org.

OBJECTIVE: Excess vitamin A may interrupt vitamin D-mediated transcription of target genes. This study investigated whether serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] concentrations were associated with lung cancer mortality, and whether this association varied by excess circulating vitamin A and vitamin A/?-carotene supplement use.
